SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

[ ] All questionnaires
[ ] Pioneer health conditions
[ ] Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
[ ] Pioneer housing
[ ] Pioneer education and churchwork
[ ] Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

JUN 11 1954
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ... Mrs. Alberta Edna "Mary Ann" McMurdo

2. Your address ... Lisdale, Saskatchewan

3. Date ... Jan. 26, 1957

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Amabel, Bruce Co., Ont.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Alexander Hunter Cunningham

   He had a sawmill in Lisdale in 1904 moved it to New Algonquin in the fall of 1906 the family still lived in Lisdale.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)

   We came to Lisdale, Sask., April 12, 1904.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

   We lived at Chipman's Hill couldn't say how long but left there for Crystal, North Dakota. The later part of October 1889, I still remember when we arrived at my grandparents' home.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).

   I was in my teens.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   My father was very fond of pioneering, in 1892 he came to Canada again took up a homestead out of Dauphin came back home intending to move the family but he took typhoid fever and was in bed two months wasn't able to go back to Dauphin till spring got word someone had cancelled the place. In 1893 he left Crystal for Thief River Falls Minnesota September 1896 we moved again to the timber lands 35 miles from Pembina, Wmn.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

    My father read a lot about the North West Territories and talked with his brother and some of the neighbors so decided to come out and have a look the neighbor moved his family and they headed for Prince Albert, our family came as far as my mother's people who lived at Melita, Man. and mother hadn't seen any of them for fourteen years we visited there all summer, father went on to Prince Albert where these people were waiting they drove out to Melita and he helped them to get settled on farms, there were two brothers with them Geo. By and Albert Wagener. He didn't see any he wanted, that fall we went back to the old home, the following year July 1903 he came to Lisdale on the train to Erwood came on a hand car part of the way walked the rest on the right of way.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation as a place to settle? Yes, they came from Ontario, Canada, and my father's mother and her children came from Ontario, Canada, and my father's mother and her children came from Ontario, Canada.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

When we arrived here there was no town just the house not even a log cabin for a dwelling. The floor was laid and one side of the first story was raised. The people that were building it were living in a tent south of the track. The town hall was on the edge of a clump of trees. The first building went up in July and moved in by September. The first door that we had was about a mile up the track a log building but they had purchased hardware and a small stack of dry goods and the post office but that fell they built and moved down on November third. We were paid by Mr. Robinson.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Yes we did go for an extended period of time and we traveled by train.
25. When was the first car used in the community? A teacher named Mr. Billy Brown.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

31. (If ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father took over the post office in 1905 and held it until the fall of 1910 when he and family moved back to Nebraska. He had the post road built there.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in having or do something in the district, mention its name, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My father organized the first Orange Lodge in Yankton.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give:

(1) name and occupation of person suggesting place name;
(2) origin and meaning of the name;
(3) date of its adoption;
(4) any changes in names since the first name was given;
(5) date and reason for change.

The town was named Yankton after one of the surveyors who mapped out the townsite, and our river is called the Rock River because the story goes the surveyors dog died and they decided to run the river up to bury and called that creek. The river was named the Batton River and the town was named when a minister walked through the creek and named it.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I have an old picture of the C.P.R. track just coming into town.

The only place some old papers could be found is at the Sisalde Recorder Office.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? ....... (indicate your preference, if any) ................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I had six sons. One was lost overseas in 1941. He was a Sgt. in the Air Force.

Sisalde Elmo Leslie McMurdo Druggist. He has 3 children: Linda, Bonnie & John.

Mission City Clarence Via McMurdo Hardware store. Has 2 children: Patricia & Ralph.

Sisalde Ralph Everett McMurdo Farmer. Sisalde. Has 3 children: Marilyn & Luke.

Edmonton Glenn Albert McMurdo Salesman in Woodland. Has 2 children: Betty Ann & Debbie.

Edmonton Ivan Miller McMurdo Salesman in Red Deer. Has 2 children: Murray & Bonnie.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The power plant, our electricity, dial phones which we just had put in last fall, there's the honey plant, wholesale houses, both fruit and machinery so many changes and important things.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
Food we ate in 1904-5

We made all our own bread in fact made our own yeast brought a starter with us from the States gathered wild hops in the woods dried them boiled them with a few potatoes added salt, sugar, ginger and flour made enough to last 6 weeks or more a cupful would make from 20 to 30 loaves of bread if we were short of bread we made biscuits, Scotch scones or pancakes. For pies we used dried fruits raisins prunes apples and apricots we brought a cow and chickens with us so made custard or cream pies also bread, rice or tapioca puddings there were no jelly or pudding powders then we made Xmas puddings the good old fashioned way mix it up take a clean piece of cotton dip in water spread out and cover with flour put the dough in tie it up and drop into a kettle of boiling water and boil 2 or 3 hours.

In the summer we walked miles picking berries raspberries, strawberries, gooseberries, black currants, low bush and high bush cranberries.

Our meat was salted meat & salt pork some canned meat salmon or canned beef unless you raised your own pork or beef which we did till the Mr Buxton started a butcher shop the fall of 1905.

We had a good garden plenty of vegetables but no one thought of canning them for winter use just put them in the cellar but they kept very well some had the potatoes in pits which they opened in the spring.
We didn't know what what a high wind was the first few years of clearing the trees and scrub away to make wheat fields there was a change, our falls were so nice.

Clothing was different then too mostly cloth coats we wore what they called "fascinators" on our heads the boys wore touques women wore felt shoes in the house, men wore mocassins and tow rubbers or what they called shoe packs.

Our roads were just prairie trails when it was raining season we used the one road till it got so full of pitch holes we would hit through the scrub and find another there was a road from Isbelle to Prince Albert my Dad drove up there with his team of drivers and cutter once or twice took a week to make the trip, in the summertime they crossed the Saskatchewan River on a ferry there were no bridges over the rivers the smaller rivers they just folded or drove through.

We did have church services every 2 weeks during the summer months which were held in Hans Boarding House. We formed a Literary Society had a reading room and met one night each, that was the fall of 1904.

We had box socials, pie socials, and so many house parties and put on concerts and teas.

The school was built 1904 started in September then we held church there till Nov 1906.

When the first church was built it was a Methodist Church and the Pentecostal have it now it was sold when the United Church was formed and we gave the Presbyterian people their choice which church to use they chose theirs.

Mrs. L. E. McMurdo
